{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3522186,"name":"mjbergman92","username":"mjbergman92","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjbergman92/{size}/219086_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-10T14:50:50.008Z","cooked":"

Recently, we adopted a similar structure to 3847 Spectrum Robots code. It makes determining the state of each subsystem much more straight forward, while using Command-Based. I wish I had figured it out myself.

When testing this weekend, unexpectedly, once we would enable the robot but not before, any of the triggers that we checked (the Trigger class I mean) were not updating.

I was unable to reproduce while simulating the robot code. The triggers were updating fine then. I don’t know what resource usage looked like, but I don’t want to jump to any conclusions just because we use a Rio 1.

Any approaches I should to finding the solution? Right now, I’m looking deep into Event Loop logic which the Trigger class is bound to when created. I’m just not sure how exactly it goes from updating to not updating once the robot is enabled.

Our code: HOC-Team-3534/OceanWhiskers

Overall, I believe it’s a memory limit issue on the Rio 1. I had disabled the web server, but that doesn’t seem to be enough. The log says 3MB of ram are available, but that doesn’t seem like enough free memory.

Nope. Entirely unrelated issue. ArmFeedforwardJNI seems broken. When not using it, the issue no longer persists. I was able to remove the issue by stop using ArmFeedforward.

@calcmogul Is there any obvious reason that the JNI used in the ArmFeedforward class causes issues and I am having to use the deprecated methods? I have now been able to reproduce the issue in simulation. Sorry to bother, but I thought it might be something you’d want to know about.

That isn’t enough information to determine the root cause, but you could try the release WPILib is making tomorrow. It will include [wpimath] Fix infinite loop in ArmFeedforward::Calculate(xₖ, vₖ, vₖ₊₁) by calcmogul · Pull Request #7745 · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub.
